keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos claimed the prosecution was not political and that he has accepted a 'very large slice of humble pie' during his incarceration.
His former colleagues, including Rep. Nick LaLota and Rep. Andrew Garbarino, criticized him for defrauding an election and said he showed no remorse or sufficient justice.
Santos stated he will not return to politics in the next decade, citing personal and political fatigue.
He expressed interest in prison reform and said his experience in solitary confinement informed his desire to work on improving the prison system non-partisanly.
Santos is no longer required to pay fines, restitution, or probation conditions as a result of the commutation.
He maintains that the original fraud allegations were unfounded and that the investment in the campaign was legitimate.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former U.S. Representative George Santos, who was convicted of fraud and served a seven-year prison sentence, was released after President Donald Trump commuted his sentence. Santos dismissed criticism from fellow Republicans like Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino, maintaining that the prosecution was not political and that he has accepted significant personal accountability. He stated that he will not return to politics in the next decade and instead plans to focus on prison reform, emphasizing that solitary confinement creates recidivism. Despite claims of remorse, his former colleagues argue he showed no genuine repentance or restitution, and the commutation has reignited debate over political clemency and accountability in public office.
title: George Santos maintains his prosecution was political, says he’s had a ‘very large slice of humble pie’
